entry.title: 公平分配 3 Price of Fairness and MMS Property
entry.content:
Objective: Explore the concept of the Price of Fairness and Maximin Share (MMS) property.

Activities: Read and present paper Optimal Bounds on the Price of Fairness for Indivisible Goods (2020) and Approximation Algorithms for Maximin Fair Division (2020).

Paper on PoF

Price of Fairness measures the worst-case loss of social welfare due to fairness constraints.

This paper: Both EF1 and 12{1\over2}21​-MMS guarantees has PoF O(n)O(\sqrt n)O(n​), where nnn is number of agents.

  • For 12{1\over2}21​-MMS, this bound holds for additive valuations.
  • For EF1, this bound holds for more general class of subadditive valuations.

Introduction

EF family omitted here

MMS family

  • 343\over443​-MMS always exist.

Fair is not the only objective of interest, another criterion is the social welfare.

Tradeoff between fairness and social welfare is measure by price of fairness, the supremum ratio of the maximum welfare of any allocation to the maximum welfare of any allocation satisfying the desired fairness notion. This measures the factor by which welfare may be lost to achieve the desired fairness.

Related Work

Caragiannis et al. Initiated PoF: PoF of Envy-freeness is between Ω(n)\Omega(\sqrt n)Ω(n​) and O(n)O(n)O(n).

Beretsimas et al. Closed the gap, bound the PoF to Θ(n)\Theta(\sqrt n)Θ(n​), matching upper bound can be achieved by maximizing the Nash welfare.

For Indivisible goods and additive valuations

  • Bei et al. showed PoF of EF1 is between Ω(n)\Omega(\sqrt n)Ω(n​) and O(n)O(n)O(n).

Contributions

Price of EF1 is O(n)O(n)O(n): subadditive valuation function

Price of PROP1: Θ(n)\Theta(n)Θ(n)

Price of 12{1\over2}21​-MMS: Θ(n)\Theta(\sqrt n)Θ(n​). For a fixed ϵ>0\epsilon\gt0ϵ>0, a (12−ϵ)(\frac{1}{2}-\epsilon)(21​−ϵ)-MMS allocation with welfare with O(n)O(\sqrt n)O(n​) factor of the optimal can be computed in polynomial time.

Preliminaries

Set [m][m][m] of indivisible goods

Set [n][n][n] of agents

Agent valuations. Each agent i∈[n]i\in[n]i∈[n] has non-negative valuation over goods.

2 valuation classes:

  • Additive vi(A+B)=vi(A)+vi(B)v_i(A+B)=v_i(A)+v_i(B)vi​(A+B)=vi​(A)+vi​(B)

  • Subadditive vi(A+B)≤vi(A)+vi(B)v_i(A+B)\le v_i(A)+v_i(B)vi​(A+B)≤vi​(A)+vi​(B)

    (Additive ⊂\subset⊂ Subadditive)

Oracle access.

  • Value query: Input iii and S⊂[m]S\subset[m]S⊂[m] output vi(S)v_i(S)vi​(S).
  • Demand query: Input iii and price pg∈R≥0p_g\in\mathbb R_{\ge0}pg​∈R≥0​ for each g∈[m]g\in[m]g∈[m], output a profit-maximizing set S∗∈arg⁡max⁡S∈[m]vi(S)−∑g∈SpgS^*\in\arg\max_{S\in[m]}v_i(S)-\sum_{g\in S}p_gS∗∈argmaxS∈[m]​vi​(S)−∑g∈S​pg​.

Allocations. omitted here

Fairness. omitted here

Social welfare. The SW of allocation A\mathcal AA, is defined as the sum of the values that the agents derive from the allocation: SW(A)=∑i=1nvi(Ai)SW(\mathcal A)=\sum_{i=1}^nv_i(A_i)SW(A)=∑i=1n​vi​(Ai​). Maximum social welfare allocation: W∗=(W1∗,W2∗,⋯ ,Wn∗)\mathcal W^*=(W_1^*,W_2^*,\cdots,W_n^*)W∗=(W1∗​,W2∗​,⋯,Wn∗​).

W∗∈arg⁡max⁡A∈Πn([m])SW(A)\mathcal W^*\in\arg\max_{\mathcal A\in\Pi_n([m])}SW(\mathcal A)W∗∈argA∈Πn​([m])max​SW(A)

OPTOPTOPT denote the optimal social welfare, i.e., OPT=SW(W∗)OPT=SW(\mathcal W^*)OPT=SW(W∗).

Price of fairness.

PoF=SW(W∗)max⁡A∈Fair AllocationSW(A)PoF={SW(\mathcal W^*)\over\max_{\mathcal A\in\text{Fair Allocation}}SW(\mathcal A)}PoF=maxA∈Fair Allocation​SW(A)SW(W∗)​

Scaling. This paper considers both scaled and unscaled valuations of agents’ valuations.

❓What does scaling here means

To ensure that agent valuations are on the same scale, much of the literature on fair division assumes that agent valuations are scaled, i.e. vi([m])=1∀i∈[n]v_i([m])=1\forall i\in[n]vi​([m])=1∀i∈[n]. Nothing that unscaled valuations are common in other areas of social choice.

In my words, scaled means for all agents, their valuations for all the goods are the same.

My question: Must the valuation here be additive?

Price of EF1

🎯🤔Theorem 1 The price of EF1 is O(n)O(\sqrt n)O(n​) for scaled subadditive valuations and Θ(n)\Theta(n)Θ(n) for unscaled subadditive valuations. Both bounds are tight even when the valuations are additive.

An Absolute Welfare Guarantee

First, we show that when agents have subadditive valuations {vi}i∈[n]\{v_i\}_{i\in[n]}{vi​}i∈[n]​ (not necessarily scaled), there always exists an EF1 allocation A\mathcal AA with social welfare SW(A)≥12n∑i=1nvi([m])SW(\mathcal A)\ge{1\over2n}\sum_{i=1}^nv_i([m])SW(A)≥2n1​∑i=1n​vi​([m]).

2 implications:

∵∑i=1nvi([m])\because\sum_{i=1}^nv_i([m])∵∑i=1n​vi​([m]) is a trivial upper bound on the optimal social welfare OPT, the result establishes am O(n)O(n)O(n) upper bound on the price of EF1.

  • For unscaled valuations, this is exactly the bound.
  • For scaled valuations, we improve this to O(n)O(\sqrt n)O(n​). Since ∑i=1nvi([m])=n\sum_{i=1}^nv_i([m])=n∑i=1n​vi​([m])=n under scaled valuations, the result gives SW(A)≥1/2SW(\mathcal A)\ge1/2SW(A)≥1/2. Hence, if OPT=O(n)OPT=O(\sqrt n)OPT=O(n​), then we have the desired O(n)O(\sqrt n)O(n​) upper bound.

This paper will analyze the case when OPT=Ω(n)OPT=\Omega(\sqrt n)OPT=Ω(n​).

This paper also give an algorithm to produce absolute welfare guarantee.

Pseudo code for Algorithm ALF-EF1-ABS:

Input: Fair-division instance I=⟨[n],[m],{vi}i∈[n]⟩\mathcal I=\lang[n],[m],\{v_i\}_{i\in[n]}\rangI=⟨[n],[m],{vi​}i∈[n]​⟩ with value-query oracle access to the subadditive valuations viv_ivi​s.

Output: An EF1 allocation B\mathcal BB with SW(B)≥12n∑i∈[n]vi([m])SW(\mathcal B)\ge{1\over2n}\sum_{i\in[n]}v_i([m])SW(B)≥2n1​∑i∈[n]​vi​([m]).

  1. Consider the weighted bipartite graph G=([n]∪[m],[n]×[m])G=([n]\cup[m],[n]\times[m])G=([n]∪[m],[n]×[m]) with weight of each edge (i,g)∈[n]×[m](i,g)\in[n]\times[m](i,g)∈[n]×[m] set as vi(g)v_i(g)vi​(g). Let π\piπ be a maximum-weight matching in GGG that matches all nodes in [n][n][n].
  2. Construct the partial allocation B′\mathcal B'B′ s.t. Bi′={π(i)}\mathcal B_i'=\{\pi(i)\}Bi′​={π(i)} for each i∈[n]i\in[n]i∈[n].
  3. Use the algorithm of Lipton et al to extend the partial EF1 allocation B′\mathcal B'B′ into a complete EF1 allocation B\mathcal BB s.t. vi(Bi)≥vi(Bi′)v_i(B_i)\ge v_i(B_i')vi​(Bi​)≥vi​(Bi′​) for each agent i∈[n]i\in[n]i∈[n].s
  4. return allocation B\mathcal BB

🤔Lemma 1. Let I=⟨[n],[m],{vi}i∈[n]⟩\mathcal I=\lang[n],[m],\{v_i\}_{i\in[n]}\rangI=⟨[n],[m],{vi​}i∈[n]​⟩ be a fair-division instance in which agent valuations are subadditive. Then, given value-query oracle access to the valuations, ALG-EF1-ABS algorithm efficiently computes an EF1 allocation B\mathcal BB with social welfare SW(B)≥12n∑i∈[n]vi([m])SW(\mathcal B)\ge{1\over2n}\sum_{i\in[n]}v_i([m])SW(B)≥2n1​∑i∈[n]​vi​([m]).

For each agent i∈[n]i\in[n]i∈[n], sort the goods as gi1,⋯ ,gimg_{i_1},\cdots,g_{i_m}gi1​​,⋯,gim​​ in a non-decreasing order of their value to agent iii i.e. vi(gi1)≥⋯≥vi(gim)v_i(g_{i_1})\ge\cdots\ge v_i(g_{i_m})vi​(gi1​​)≥⋯≥vi​(gim​​), and let Gi={gi1,⋯ ,gin}G_i=\{g_{i_1},\cdots,g_{i_n}\}Gi​={gi1​​,⋯,gin​​} be the set of nnn most valuable goods to agent iii.

Consider a subgraph G′=([n]∪[m],E′)G'=([n]\cup[m],E')G′=([n]∪[m],E′) of the weighted bipartite graph GGG constructed in line 1 of the algorithm, in which we only retain the edges E′={(i,g):i∈[n],g∈Gi}E'=\{(i,g):i\in[n],g\in G_i\}E′={(i,g):i∈[n],g∈Gi​} (i.e. from each agent iii to her nnn most valuable goods). Because G′G'G′ is nnn-left-regular, it can be decomposed into nnn disjoint left-perfect matchings M1,⋯ ,MnM_1,\cdots,M_nM1​,⋯,Mn​, this is an easy consequence of Halls’ theorem. Due to the pigeonhole principle, one of M1,⋯ ,MnM_1,\cdots,M_nM1​,⋯,Mn​ must have weight at least 1n1\over nn1​. We have

∑i∈[n]vi(π(i))=SW(B′)≥1n⋅∑i∈[n],g∈Givi(g)\sum_{i\in[n]}v_i(\pi(i))=SW(\mathcal B')\ge{1\over n}\cdot\sum_{i\in[n],g\in G_i}v_i(g)i∈[n]∑​vi​(π(i))=SW(B′)≥n1​⋅i∈[n],g∈Gi​∑​vi​(g)

B′\mathcal B'B′ assigns a single good to each agent; hence, it is trivially EF1. The algorithm makes sure that B\mathcal BB is the extension of B′\mathcal B'B′ s.t. vi(Bi)≥vi(Bi′)v_i(B_i)\ge v_i(B_i')vi​(Bi​)≥vi​(Bi′​). Thus,

SW(B)≥1n∑i∈[n]∑g∈Givi(g)SW(\mathcal B)\ge{1\over n}\sum_{i\in[n]}\sum_{g\in G_i}v_i(g)SW(B)≥n1​i∈[n]∑​g∈Gi​∑​vi​(g)

B\mathcal BB is EF1, thus for each i,j∈[n]i,j\in[n]i,j∈[n], there exists Sj⊆BjS_j\subseteq B_jSj​⊆Bj​ with ∣Sj∣≤1|S_j|\le1∣Sj​∣≤1 s.t. vi(Bi)≥vi(Bj╲Sj)≥vi(Bj)−vi(Sj)v_i(B_i)\ge v_i(B_j\diagdown S_j)\ge v_i(B_j)-v_i(S_j)vi​(Bi​)≥vi​(Bj​╲Sj​)≥vi​(Bj​)−vi​(Sj​) (subadditive for last inequality). Summing this inequality over j∈[n]j\in[n]j∈[n], we get

n⋅vi(Bi)≥∑j∈[n]vi(Bj)−∑j∈[n]vi(Sj)≥vi([m])−∑j∈[n]vi(Sj)≥vi([m])−∑g∈Givi(g),n\cdot v_i(B_i)\ge\sum_{j\in[n]}v_i(B_j)-\sum_{j\in[n]}v_i(S_j)\\\ge v_i([m])-\sum_{j\in[n]}v_i(S_j)\ge v_i([m])-\sum_{g\in G_i}v_i(g),n⋅vi​(Bi​)≥j∈[n]∑​vi​(Bj​)−j∈[n]∑​vi​(Sj​)≥vi​([m])−j∈[n]∑​vi​(Sj​)≥vi​([m])−g∈Gi​∑​vi​(g),

where the penultimate inequality holds because BjB_jBj​s form a partition of [m][m][m] and the last inequality follows from subadditivity. SjS_jSj​s are disjoint and have cardinality at most 111, and GiG_iGi​ is the set of nnn most valuable goods to iii. Summing over i∈[n]i\in[n]i∈[n], we get

n⋅∑i∈[n]vi(Bi)=n⋅SW(B)≥∑i∈[n]vi([m])−∑i∈[n]∑g∈Givi(g).n\cdot\sum_{i\in[n]}v_i(B_i)=n\cdot SW(\mathcal B)\ge\sum_{i\in[n]}v_i([m])-\sum_{i\in[n]}\sum_{g\in G_i}v_i(g).n⋅i∈[n]∑​vi​(Bi​)=n⋅SW(B)≥i∈[n]∑​vi​([m])−i∈[n]∑​g∈Gi​∑​vi​(g).

Substituting equation, we get the desired bound

n⋅SW(B)+n⋅SW(B)≥∑i∈[n]vi([m])−∑i∈[n]∑g∈Givi(g)+∑i∈[n]∑g∈Givi(g)=∑i∈[n]vi([m])n\cdot SW(\mathcal B)+n\cdot SW(\mathcal B)\ge\sum_{i\in[n]}v_i([m])-\sum_{i\in[n]}\sum_{g\in G_i}v_i(g)+\sum_{i\in[n]}\sum_{g\in G_i}v_i(g)\\=\sum_{i\in[n]}v_i([m])n⋅SW(B)+n⋅SW(B)≥i∈[n]∑​vi​([m])−i∈[n]∑​g∈Gi​∑​vi​(g)+i∈[n]∑​g∈Gi​∑​vi​(g)=i∈[n]∑​vi​([m])

which implies SW(B)≥12n∑i∈[n]vi([m])SW(\mathcal B)\ge{1\over 2n}\sum_{i\in[n]}v_i([m])SW(B)≥2n1​∑i∈[n]​vi​([m]) as needed.

The Case of High Optimal Welfare

Lemma 1 focuses on fair division with scaled subadditive valuations in which the optimal social welfare is Ω(n)\Omega(\sqrt n)Ω(n​), which means we can sacrifice O(n)O(\sqrt n)O(n​) of the welfare in OPT, obtain O(n)O(\sqrt n)O(n​) approximation to the remaining welfare through an EF1 allocation, and yet achieve O(n)O(\sqrt n)O(n​) approximation to OPT.

In particular, this paper presents an algorithm that efficiently finds an EF1 allocation A\mathcal AA with social welfare SW(A)≥OPT−2n12nSW(\mathcal A)\ge{OPT-2\sqrt n\over12\sqrt n}SW(A)≥12n​OPT−2n​​.

W∗\mathcal W^*W∗ corresponds to optimal social welfare OPTOPTOPT.

However, for subadditive valuations, computing such an allocation is NP-hard under both value queries and demand queries.

Using a polynomial number of value queries, it’s Θ(m)\Theta(\sqrt m)Θ(m​) best possible approximation to the optimal social welfare. (Too loose)

Starting with high-welfare allocation W\mathcal WW returned by Feige’s Algorithm, the algorithm works as follows: It first indexes mmm goods as g1,⋯ ,gmg_1,\cdots,g_mg1​,⋯,gm​ s.t. the goods n each WiW_iWi​ receive consecutive indices. Alternatively, consider a line graph L=([m],E)L=([m],E)L=([m],E) over the set of goods with edges E={(gk,gk+1):k∈[m−1]}E=\{(g_k,g_{k+1}):k\in[m-1]\}E={(gk​,gk+1​):k∈[m−1]}. Then each WiW_iWi​ induces a connected subgraph of LLL.

Definition of line graph: Let L=([m],E)L=([m],E)L=([m],E) be a line graph over the goods, we say that S⊆[m]S\subseteq[m]S⊆[m] is a connected bundle in LLL if SSS induces a connected subgraph of LLL. Given a partial allocation P\mathcal PP, define U(P)\mathcal U(\mathcal P)U(P) as the set of connected components of LLL that remain after moving the allocated goods ∪i∈[n]Pi\cup_{i\in[n]}P_i∪i∈[n]​Pi​. We refer to U∈U(P)U\in\mathcal U(\mathcal P)U∈U(P) as an unassigned connected bundle.

Algorithm ALG-EF1-HIGH builds a partial allocation P\mathcal PP by giving each agent iii her most valuable good from WiW_iWi​. This allocation satisfies: EF1, and each PiP_iPi​ is a connected bundle in LLL. (trivial) The algorithm then iteratively updates P\mathcal PP to improve its social welfare while maintaining both properties.

In particular, at every iteration, the algorithm computes the set of unassigned connected bundles U(P)\mathcal U(\mathcal P)U(P). Removing nnn connected bundles from P\mathcal PP can create at most n+1n+1n+1 unassigned connected bundles.

If there is an unassigned connected bundle UUU that some agent envies, then the algorithm finds an inclusion-wise minimal subset of UUU that is envied and allocates it to an envious agent.

  • This paper argues that inclusion-wise minimality preserves the EF1 of P\mathcal PP.
  • This paper also argues that this iterative process terminates at a partial allocation P\mathcal PP that satisfies the desired social welfare guarantee.

ALG-EF1-HIGH is extended from Lipton et al, which computes EF1 allocation without losing social welfare.

Pseudo code omitted here.

🤔Lemma 2. When ALG-EF1-HIGH is run on a fair division instance I=⟨[n],[m],{vi}i∈[n]⟩\mathcal I=\lang[n],[m],\{v_i\}_{i\in[n]}\rangI=⟨[n],[m],{vi​}i∈[n]​⟩ with subadditive valuations, the following hold regarding the partial allocation Pt\mathcal P^tPt constructed after ttt iterations of the while loop.

  1. If t≥1t\ge1t≥1, then for each agent i∈[n]i\in[n]i∈[n], either Pit=Pit−1P_i^t=P_i^{t-1}Pit​=Pit−1​ or vi(Pit)≥vi(Pit−1)v_i(P_i^t)\ge v_i(P_i^{t-1})vi​(Pit​)≥vi​(Pit−1​).
  2. For each agent i∈[n]i\in[n]i∈[n], PiP_iPi​ is a connected bundle under the line graph LLL constructed in checking whether there exists agent envying a U∈U(P)U\in\mathcal U(\mathcal P)U∈U(P).
  3. PtP^tPt is EF1.

1. and 2. are trivial.

For 3., using induction.

🤔Lemma 3. When ALG-EF1-HIGH is run on a fair division instance I\mathcal II with subadditive valuations, the following hold:

  1. The while loop terminates after T=O(nm2)T=O(nm^2)T=O(nm2) iterations.
  2. The partial allocation PT\mathcal P^TPT constructed at the end of the while loop satisfies vi(PiT)≥vi(U)v_i(P_i^T)\ge v_i(U)vi​(PiT​)≥vi​(U) for every agent i∈[n]i\in[n]i∈[n] and unassigned connected bundle U∈U(PT)U\in\mathcal U(\mathcal P^T)U∈U(PT).

O(m2)O(m^2)O(m2) possible connected bundles in L⇒L\RarrL⇒ an agent’s assignment can only be updated O(m2)O(m^2)O(m2) times. There are nnn agents in total.

The while loop would not have terminated if vi(PiT)<vi(U)v_i(P_i^T)\lt v_i(U)vi​(PiT​)<vi​(U) for any agent iii and any unassigned connected bundle UUU.

🤔Lemma 4. Given a fair division instance I\mathcal II with scaled subadditive valuations, ALG-EF1-HIGH terminates in polynomial time and returns an EF1 allocation A\mathcal AA satisfying

SW(A)≥OPT12n−16.SW(\mathcal A)\ge{OPT\over12\sqrt n}-{1\over6}.SW(A)≥12n​OPT​−61​.

where OPTOPTOPT is the optimal social welfare achievable in instance I\mathcal II.

Feige’s algorithm satisfies SW(W)≥12OPTSW(\mathcal W)\ge{1\over2}OPTSW(W)≥21​OPT. Let the while loop in ALG-EF1-HIGH terminate with partial allocation P\mathcal PP; that is P=PT\mathcal P=\mathcal P^TP=PT, where TTT is # of iterations. Lemma 3 ensures that the while loop terminates. It suffices to show

n+6n⋅SW(P)≥SW(W).\sqrt n+6\sqrt n\cdot SW(\mathcal P)\ge SW(\mathcal W).n​+6n​⋅SW(P)≥SW(W).

By lemma 2, P\mathcal PP is EF1. Also, note that the algorithm of Lipton et al can extend EF1 allocation P\mathcal PP into a complete EF1 allocation A\mathcal AA with SW(A)≥SW(P)SW(\mathcal A)\ge SW(\mathcal P)SW(A)≥SW(P). Hence the inequality above along with SW(W)≥12OPTSW(\mathcal W)\ge{1\over2}OPTSW(W)≥21​OPT completes the proof of the lemma 4.

Due to lemma 2, each PiP_iPi​ is a connected bundle in the line graph LLL. Hence, removing the goods allocated in P\mathcal PP creates at most n+1n+1n+1 connected components, i.e. ∣U(P)∣<n+1|\mathcal U(\mathcal P)|\lt n+1∣U(P)∣<n+1. Let T(P)={Pj:j∈[n]}∪U(P)\mathcal T(\mathcal P)=\{P_j:j\in[n]\}\cup\mathcal U(\mathcal P)T(P)={Pj​:j∈[n]}∪U(P) be the collection of the assigned and unassigned in LLL created by P\mathcal PP. Hence ∣T(P)∣<2n+1|\mathcal T(\mathcal P)|\lt2n+1∣T(P)∣<2n+1. For each agent i∈[n]i\in[n]i∈[n], let Qi\mathcal Q_iQi​ denote the bundles in T(P)\mathcal T(\mathcal P)T(P) that intersect with WiW_iWi​, i.e., Qi={S∈T(P):S∩Wi≠∅}\mathcal Q_i=\{S\in\mathcal T(\mathcal P):S\cap W_i\neq\empty\}Qi​={S∈T(P):S∩Wi​=∅}. write qi=∣Qi∣q_i=|\mathcal Q_i|qi​=∣Qi​∣.

While W\mathcal WW forms a partition of LLL into at most nnn connected components. This, along with the observation that LLL is a line graph, can be used to bound the total number of intersections between the two. We can move a marker from left to right, keeping track of the bundle from W\mathcal WW and the bundle from T(P)\mathcal T(\mathcal P)T(P) that contain the current good. Every time the marker encounters a new intersection, it must have entered either a new bundle from WWW or a new bundle from T(P)\mathcal T(\mathcal P)T(P). Thus, we have

∑i∈[n]qi≤(2n+1)+n=3n+1.\sum_{i\in[n]}q_i\le(2n+1)+n=3n+1.i∈[n]∑​qi​≤(2n+1)+n=3n+1.

Next, we partition the set of agents [n][n][n] based on their qiq_iqi​ value. Let H={i∈[n]:qi>3n}H=\{i\in[n]:q_i\gt3\sqrt n\}H={i∈[n]:qi​>3n​} and Hc={i∈[n]:qi≤3n}H^c=\{i\in[n]:q_i\le3\sqrt n\}Hc={i∈[n]:qi​≤3n​}. Above inequality implies ∣H∣≤n|H|\le\sqrt n∣H∣≤n​. This along with the observation that the valuation are scaled, gives us

∑i∈Hvi(Wi)≤∣H∣≤n\sum_{i\in H}v_i(W_i)\le|H|\le\sqrt ni∈H∑​vi​(Wi​)≤∣H∣≤n​

Next, we bound vi(Wi)v_i(W_i)vi​(Wi​) for i∈Hci\in H^ci∈Hc. By definition of Qi\mathcal Q_iQi​, we have vi(Wi)=∑S∈Qivi(S∩Wi)v_i(W_i)=\sum_{S\in\mathcal Q_i}v_i(S\cap W_i)vi​(Wi​)=∑S∈Qi​​vi​(S∩Wi​). We break the sum into 2 parts, S∈U(P)S\in\mathcal U(\mathcal P)S∈U(P) or S∈PS\in\mathcal PS∈P.

  1. If S∈U(P)S\in\mathcal U(\mathcal P)S∈U(P), by lemma 3, we have vi(S∩Wi)≤vi(S)≤vi(Pi)≤2vi(Pi)v_i(S\cap W_i)\le v_i(S)\le v_i(P_i)\le 2v_i(P_i)vi​(S∩Wi​)≤vi​(S)≤vi​(Pi​)≤2vi​(Pi​).
  2. If S∈PS\in\mathcal PS∈P, then S=PjS=P_jS=Pj​ for some agent j∈[n]j\in[n]j∈[n]. Let P^j=Pj∩Wi\hat P_j=P_j\cap W_iP^j​=Pj​∩Wi​. By definition of Qi\mathcal Q_iQi​, P^j≠∅\hat P_j\neq\emptyP^j​=∅. ∵P\because\mathcal P∵P is EF1 and viv_ivi​ is monotone, agent iii does not envy the bundle PjP_jPj​ up to one good in it. Thus, there exists a good g^∈P^j\hat g\in\hat P_jg^​∈P^j​ s.t. vi(Pi)≥vi(P^j╲{g^})≥vi(P^j)−vi(g^)v_i(P_i)\ge v_i(\hat P_j\diagdown\{\hat g\})\ge v_i(\hat P_j)-v_i(\hat g)vi​(Pi​)≥vi​(P^j​╲{g^​})≥vi​(P^j​)−vi​(g^​), where the last transition uses subadditivity of viv_ivi​. 🎯🤔Theorem 2. The price of 121\over221​-MMS is Θ(n)\Theta(\sqrt n)Θ(n​) for scaled additive valuations and Θ(n)\Theta(n)Θ(n) for unscaled additive valuations.

An Absolute Welfare Guarantee

First, this paper shows that when agents have additive valuations, there always exists a 121\over221​-MMS allocation A\mathcal AA with social welfare SW(A)≥13n∑i=1nvi([m])SW(\mathcal A)\ge{1\over3n}\sum_{i=1}^nv_i([m])SW(A)≥3n1​∑i=1n​vi​([m]). Algorithm ALG-MMS-ABS computes such an allocation efficiently.

The result is two fold

  1. For both scaled and unscaled valuations, this establishes that the price of 121\over221​-MMS is O(n)O(n)O(n). (trivial)
  2. For unscaled valuations, this is precisely the bound.
  3. For scaled valuations, we need to improve this to O(n)O(\sqrt n)O(n​).

Pseudo code for ALG-MMS-ABS:

Input: A fair division instance I\mathcal II, additive valuations {vi}i∈[n]\{v_i\}_{i\in[n]}{vi​}i∈[n]​.

Output: A 121\over221​-MMS allocation B\mathcal BB with SW(B)≥13n∑i=1nvi([m])SW(\mathcal B)\ge{1\over3n}\sum_{i=1}^nv_i([m])SW(B)≥3n1​∑i=1n​vi​([m]).

  1. Initialize set of agents A=[n]A=[n]A=[n], set of goods G=[m]G=[m]G=[m] and bundles Bi=∅B_i=\emptyBi​=∅ for all i∈[n]i\in[n]i∈[n].
  2. while there exists agent i∈Ai\in Ai∈A and good g∈Gg\in Gg∈G s.t. vi(g)≥12∣A∣vi(G)v_i(g)\ge{1\over2|A|}v_i(G)vi​(g)≥2∣A∣1​vi​(G) do
    • set (i′,g′)∈arg⁡max⁡(i,g)∈A×G:vi(g)≥12∣A∣vi(G)vi(g)(i',g')\in\arg\max_{(i,g)\in A\times G:v_i(g)\ge{1\over2|A|}v_i(G)}v_i(g)(i′,g′)∈argmax(i,g)∈A×G:vi​(g)≥2∣A∣1​vi​(G)​vi​(g)
    • set Bi′={g′}B_{i'}=\{g'\}Bi′​={g′} and update A←A╲{i′}A\gets A\diagdown\{i'\}A←A╲{i′} along with G←G╲{g′}G\gets G\diagdown\{g'\}G←G╲{g′}
  3. end while
  4. efficiently compute a Prop1 allocation (Bi)i∈A(B_i)_{i\in A}(Bi​)i∈A​ of the fair division instance ⟨A,G,{vi}i∈A⟩\lang A,G,\{v_i\}_{i\in A}\rang⟨A,G,{vi​}i∈A​⟩
  5. return allocation B=(B1,⋯ ,Bn)\mathcal B=(B_1,\cdots,B_n)B=(B1​,⋯,Bn​).

The algorithm is a refinement of the algorithm of Amandatidis et al. for computing a 121\over221​-MMS allocation: in while loop, we use arg⁡max⁡\arg\maxargmax to break ties. They had proven the algorithm always produce 121\over221​-MMS. It remains to prove that the desired welfare holds for results.

To analyze the bounds, we let ttt denote the number of iterations of the while loop in ALG-MMS-ABS. We re-index the agents s.t. agent 111 through ttt receive, in order, a good in this while loop. Each agent i∈[t]i\in[t]i∈[t] is assigned a good in iii-th iteration of the loop. The remaining n−tn-tn−t agents receive a bundle through the Prop1 allocation computed after while loop.

The Case of High Optimal Welfare

This paper proposes new algorithm, ALG-MMS-HIGH, to compute O(n)O(\sqrt n)O(n​) welfare on 121\over221​-MMS.

Computing MMSiMMS_iMMSi​ for each agent iii is NP-hard, there exists a polynomial-time approximation scheme (PTAS) for it. For a fixed ϵ∈(0,1)\epsilon\in(0,1)ϵ∈(0,1), this PTAS can compute an estimate Zi∈[(1−ϵ)MMSi,MMSi]Z_i\in[(1-\epsilon)MMS_i,MMS_i]Zi​∈[(1−ϵ)MMSi​,MMSi​] for each agent iii in polynomial time. We pass these estimates as input to ALG-MMS-HIGH, which runs in polynomial time and yields a (12−ϵ)({1\over2}-\epsilon)(21​−ϵ)-MMS allocation with the desired welfare guarantee.

(OPTOPTOPT is the optimal social welfare in I\mathcal II)

Proof of Theorem 2

For unscaled valuations: lemma 6 shows that ALG-MMS-ABS returns a 121\over221​-MMS allocation B\mathcal BB with social welfare SW(B)≥13n∑i=1nvi([m])SW(\mathcal B)\ge{1\over3n}\sum_{i=1}^nv_i([m])SW(B)≥3n1​∑i=1n​vi​([m]). Because OPT is trivially upper bounded as OPT≤∑i=1nvi([m])OPT\le\sum_{i=1}^nv_i([m])OPT≤∑i=1n​vi​([m]), we have that the price of 121\over221​-MMS is at most 3n=O(n)3n=O(n)3n=O(n). (To show this bound is tight, this paper gives an instance)

For scaled valuations: lemma 6 implies ALG-MMS-ABS returns a 121\over221​-MMS allocation B\mathcal BB with SW(B)≥13n∑i=1nvi([m])=13SW(\mathcal B)\ge{1\over3n}\sum_{i=1}^nv_i([m])={1\over3}SW(B)≥3n1​∑i=1n​vi​([m])=31​ for scaled valuations. Hence, if OPT≤5nOPT\le5\sqrt nOPT≤5n​, then the 121\over221​-MMS allocation returned by ALG-MMS-ABS gives a 15n15\sqrt n15n​ approximation to the optimal social welfare.

Otherwise, suppose OPT≥5nOPT\ge5\sqrt nOPT≥5n​. Then by lemma 7, we know that ALG-MMS-HIGH returns an allocation with social welfare SW(B)≥OPT−4n3n≥OPT−4/5OPT3n−OPT15nSW(\mathcal B)\ge{OPT-4\sqrt n\over 3\sqrt n}\ge{OPT-4/5OPT\over3\sqrt n}-{OPT\over15\sqrt n}SW(B)≥3n​OPT−4n​​≥3n​OPT−4/5OPT​−15n​OPT​. Hence, in this case, the 121\over221​-MMS allocation returned by ALG-MMS-HIGH provides a 15n15\sqrt n15n​ approximation to OPTOPTOPT.

(For lower bound, this paper also gives an instance)

Discussion

Price of EF1: O(n)O(\sqrt n)O(n​) when valuations are subadditive

  • Θ(n)\Theta(\sqrt n)Θ(n​) even if valuations are additive.

Price of 121\over221​-MMS is Θ(n)\Theta(\sqrt n)Θ(n​) when agent valuations arer additive.

Research outlook:

  1. Analyze the price of 121\over221​-MMS under more general valuation classes.

    Consider other combinations of fairness and efficiency guarantees:

    • EF1 + PO (Pareto optimality), EF1 + fPO (fractional Pareto optimality)
    • Price of α\alphaα-MMS for α>12\alpha\gt{1\over2}α>21​. At least 343\over443​-MMS always exists.
    • Price of α\alphaα-GMMS. GMMS ⇒\Rarr⇒ MMS. 121\over221​-GMMS always exists.
    • Price of EFX. It remains to be solved the existence of EFX for agents more than 3.

  2. Analyze the PoF when the items are chores, （简单来说就是物品的估值可以为负）or a mixture of goods and chores.

The formal definitions fairness and corresponding prices are well-understood within fair division, but they are much less explored within other scenarios, such as social choice theory (voting or matching).

Paper on MMS

Additive and submodular valuation

A valuation function is considered submodular if adding an item to a smaller set increases its value more than adding the same item to a larger set.

232\over332​-MMS always exists and can be found in polynomial time. This paper complement these results by developing a simple and efficient algorithm that achieves the same approximation guarantee.

This paper approximates MMS under submodular valuations. It shows that when the valuations of agents are non-negative, monotone and submodular, then a 0.210.210.21-MMS is guaranteed to exist.

0.21≈13(1−1e)0.21\approx{1\over3}(1-{1\over e})0.21≈31​(1−e1​)

Introduction

💡Personal comment: A very clear explanation original idea for the Maximin Share: Let agent iii partition the goods into nnn bundles, then let others choose before iii choose a bundle. Then agent iii has incentive to maximize the the bundle with minimal value she partitioned.

This paper extends the previous work into both additive and submodular valuations.

Main Results and Techniques

Additive Valuations

This paper presents a polynomial time algorithm that finds a 232\over332​-MMS under additive valuations. The algorithm is simple and combinatorial.

The algorithm consists of two parts. First, reducing the problem of finding a maximin fair allocation to a restricted setting where the agents value goods in the same order. This reduction preserves maximin fairness in the sense that the ggg-th good in the reduced instance corresponds to the right to select a good in round ggg.

With the reduction, this paper develops an efficient algorithm to find 232\over332​-MMS allocation for ordered instances. To obtain the result, do some modification on envy-graph algorithm.

(An arbitrary EF1 doesn’t necessarily imply approx-MMS) But with the order, an instance of the EF1 algorithm indeed finds an allocation with desired maximin fairness guarantee.

Submodular Valuations

When valuations are non-negative, monotone and submodular, then a 0.210.210.21-MMS is guaranteed to exist and can be efficiently computed via a simple round-robin algorithm.

This paper analyzes this simple algorithm by employing the concept of multilinear extensions.

For each agent iii, the expected value of a random subset is at least 1−1e1-{1\over e}1−e1​ times the maximin share of iii.

Since computing the maximin share is NP-hard, the algorithm works with estimates τi\tau_iτi​ for agent iii of the maximin shares. Each estimate τi\tau_iτi​ is initialized to be greater than the corresponding maximin share. The methods ensures none of them significantly smaller than the maximin shares.

In our algorithm, we first perform a preprocessing step wherein high-valued goods are assigned as singleton bundles. In particular, if for an agent iii there exists an unallocated good of value at least 0.21τi0.21\tau_i0.21τi​, then we allocate the good to the agent and remove iii (and the now assigned good) from consideration. The leftover (low-valued) goods are partitioned among the remaining agents (who have not received a good yet) in a round-robin manner. In each round, the participating agents greedily select an unallocated good one after the other, i.e. in each round, every agent iii is assigned a good that leads to the maximum possible increase in iii’s valuation.

Under submodular valuations, a uniformly random allocation is (1−1e)(1-{1\over e})(1−e1​) times iii’s maximin share.

Remark: additive ⊆\subseteq⊆ submodular. We can get stronger approximation guarantee on additive valuations.

Chores (goods with negative values): 434\over334​-approximate maximin fair allocation can be efficiently computed when agents have additive valuations for chores.

The envy graph algorithm is applied similarly between goods version and chores version.

Additive Valuations

In this section, the paper presents an new algorithm that efficiently finds a 232\over332​-MMS under additive valuations.

Contribution: the algorithm is simple and combinatorial.

🎯🤔Theorem 1. Given a set of nnn agents with additive valuations {vi}i∈[n]\{v_i\}_{i\in[n]}{vi​}i∈[n]​ for a set of mmm indivisible goods, we can find a partition A\mathcal AA in polynomial time that satisfies

vi(Ai)≥2n3n−1μiv_i(A_i)\ge{2n\over3n-1}\mu_ivi​(Ai​)≥3n−12n​μi​

for all i∈[n]i\in[n]i∈[n]. Here μi\mu_iμi​ is the maximin share of agent iii.

Proof in two parts. First, we show the problem can be reduced to a restricted setting where the agents value the goods in the same order. Second, we develop a 232\over332​-approximation for this restricted setting.

The Reduction of Bouveret and Lemaître

An instance is an ordered instance iff ∃\exist∃ a total ordering ≺\prec≺ over [m][m][m] s.t. ∀i∈[n]\forall i\in[n]∀i∈[n] and g,g′∈[m]g,g'\in[m]g,g′∈[m], s.t. g≺g′g\prec g'g≺g′, we have vi,g≥vi,g′v_{i,g}\ge v_{i,g'}vi,g​≥vi,g′​. i.e. vi,1≥vi,2≥⋯vi,mv_{i,1}\ge v_{i,2}\ge\cdots v_{i,m}vi,1​≥vi,2​≥⋯vi,m​.

Given a fair division I=([n],[m],{vi}i∈[n])I=([n],[m],\{v_i\}_{i\in[n]})I=([n],[m],{vi​}i∈[n]​), the algorithm constructs an ordered instance as follows:

  1. For every agent iii, ∃\exist∃ a permutation σi:[m]→[m]\sigma_i:[m]\rarr[m]σi​:[m]→[m] s.t. ∀g,g′∈[m]\forall g,g'\in[m]∀g,g′∈[m] with g<g′g\lt g'g<g′, we have vi,σi(g)≥vi,σi(g′)v_{i,\sigma_i(g)}\ge v_{i,\sigma_i(g')}vi,σi​(g)​≥vi,σi​(g′)​. Using these permutations, we define a new valuation function vi′v_i'vi′​ for every agent iii by setting vi,g′=vi,σi(g)v_{i,g}'=v_{i,\sigma_i(g)}vi,g′​=vi,σi​(g)​ for all g∈[m]g\in[m]g∈[m].

    i.e. for iii, the value of ggg-th good in the new instance is equal to the ggg-th largest valuation of iii in the original instance.

    Denote I′=([n],[m],{vi′}i∈[n])I'=([n],[m],\{v_i'\}_{i\in[n]})I′=([n],[m],{vi′​}i∈[n]​) as the ordered instance of III. Note that we can find the ordered instance of III in O(nmlog⁡m)O(nm\log m)O(nmlogm) time.

  2. Bouveret and Lemaître showed that if there is an allocation A′\mathcal A'A′ that guarantees every agent her maximin share in I′I'I′, then there is an allocation A\mathcal AA that guarantees every agent her maximin share in III.

    Moreover, given a maximin fair allocation A′\mathcal A'A′ for I′I'I′, a maximin fair allocation A\mathcal AA for III can be found in polynomial time.

Pseudo code for ALGBL

Input: III with A′\mathcal A'A′ for the ordered instance I′I'I′.

Output: A\mathcal AA

  1. For all i∈[n]i\in[n]i∈[n] and g∈Ai′g\in A_i'g∈Ai′​ set pg=ip_g=ipg​=i. // this defines a sequence of agents
  2. Initialize allocation A\mathcal AA with Ai=∅A_i=\emptyAi​=∅, for all i∈[n]i\in[n]i∈[n]. And initialize R←[m]R\gets[m]R←[m].
  3. for g=1g=1g=1 to mmm do
    • pick k∈arg⁡max⁡g′∈R{vpg(g′)}k\in\arg\max_{g'\in R}\{v_{p_g}(g')\}k∈argmaxg′∈R​{vpg​​(g′)}
    • update Apg←Apg∪{k}A_{p_g}\gets A_{p_g}\cup\{k\}Apg​​←Apg​​∪{k} and R←R╲{k}R\gets R\diagdown\{k\}R←R╲{k}
  4. return A\mathcal AA

🎯🤔Theorem 2. Given a maximin fair division instance III and scalars {αi∈R}i=1n\{\alpha_i\in\mathbb R\}_{i=1}^n{αi​∈R}i=1n​, let I′I'I′ be the ordered instance of III. If there exists an allocation A′\mathcal A'A′ that satisfies vi′(Ai′)≥αiv_i'(A_i')\ge\alpha_ivi′​(Ai′​)≥αi​ for all i∈[n]i\in[n]i∈[n], then there exists an allocation A\mathcal AA s.t. vi(Ai)≥αiv_i(A_i)\ge\alpha_ivi​(Ai​)≥αi​ for all i∈[n]i\in[n]i∈[n]. Furthermore, given III and A′\mathcal A'A′, ALGBL computes the allocation A\mathcal AA in polynomial time.

Obviously polynomial time. We only need to show it computes required allocation.

Let kgk_gkg​ denote the good allocated in the ggg-th iteration of the second for-loop in ALGBL. Now considering agent iii, suppose that g∈Ai′g\in A_i'g∈Ai′​ then kg∈Aik_g\in A_ikg​∈Ai​. Note that, for any g≠g′g\neq g'g=g′, since a good is removed from the set RRR after it is allocated. Before the ggg-th iteration of the second for loop in ALGBL, exactly g−1g-1g−1 goods had been allocated.

Therefore, kgk_gkg​ is among the top ggg goods for agent iii. Hence, the condition that vi′(Ai′)≥αiv_i'(A_i')\ge\alpha_ivi′​(Ai′​)≥αi​ gives us vi(Ai)≥αiv_i(A_i)\ge\alpha_ivi​(Ai​)≥αi​ for all iii. Q.E.D.

Corollary: Given a maximin fair division instance III and α∈R\alpha\in\mathbb Rα∈R write I′I'I′ to denote the ordered instance of III and μi\mu_iμi​ to denote the maximin share of agent iii in III. If there exists an allocation A′\mathcal A'A′ satisfying vi′(Ai′)≥αμi′v_i'(A_i')\ge\alpha\mu_i'vi′​(Ai′​)≥αμi′​, there also exists A\mathcal AA satisfying vi(Ai)≥αμiv_i(A_i)\ge\alpha\mu_ivi​(Ai​)≥αμi​. And can be computed in polynomial time.

Envy Graph Algorithm

Envy-graph Elimination algorithm, omitted here.

ALGEG algorithm returns an EFX allocation. Similar to Top Trading Cycle algorithm.

Pseudo code omitted here.

Majorization

The concept is sued to establishing the desired approximation guarantee.

A multi-set XXX is related to another multi-set YYY iff the prefix sums of the sorted version XXX are at least as large as the prefix sums of the sorted version of YYY.

Definition of majorization: A multi-set X={xi∈R∣1≤i≤n}X=\{x_i\in\mathbb R|1\le i\le n\}X={xi​∈R∣1≤i≤n} is said to majorize another multi-set Y={yi∈R∣1≤i≤n}Y=\{y_i\in\mathbb R|1\le i\le n\}Y={yi​∈R∣1≤i≤n} iff

∑i=1kx(i)≥∑i=1ky(i)∀1≤k<nand∑i=1nx(i)=∑i=1ny(i)\sum_{i=1}^kx_{(i)}\ge\sum_{i=1}^ky_{(i)}\forall1\le k\lt n\\and\\\sum_{i=1}^nx_{(i)}=\sum_{i=1}^ny_{(i)}i=1∑k​x(i)​≥i=1∑k​y(i)​∀1≤k<nandi=1∑n​x(i)​=i=1∑n​y(i)​

Here x(i)x_{(i)}x(i)​ and y(i)y_{(i)}y(i)​ is the iii-th largest element of XXX and YYY respectively.

🤔Proposition 1. (easy)

Let v,v′∈Rv,v'\in\mathbb Rv,v′∈R be two elements of a multi-set AAA of real numbers. In addition, let u,u′∈Ru,u'\in\mathbb Ru,u′∈R satisfy u+u′=v+v′u+u'=v+v'u+u′=v+v′ and ∣u−u′∣<∣v−v′∣|u-u'|\lt|v-v'|∣u−u′∣<∣v−v′∣. Then AAA majorizes (A╲{v,v′})∪{u,u′}(A\diagdown\{v,v'\})\cup\{u,u'\}(A╲{v,v′})∪{u,u′}.

This is trivial and obvious.

因为 u,u′u,u'u,u′ 中的最大值小于 v,v′v,v'v,v′ 中的最大值，这使得 AAA 的前缀和加到 v,v′v,v'v,v′ 中最大值的时候一定会大于等于 (A╲{v,v′})∪{u,u′}(A\diagdown\{v,v'\})\cup\{u,u'\}(A╲{v,v′})∪{u,u′} 加到相应的位置上的前缀和。

Proof of Theorem 1

It remains to show that v1(A1)≥2n3n−1μ1v_1(A_1)\ge{2n\over3n-1}\mu_1v1​(A1​)≥3n−12n​μ1​. (An analogous argument establishes the desired bound, vi(Ai)≥2n3n−1μi∀i∈[n]v_i(A_i)\ge{2n\over3n-1}\mu_i\forall i\in[n]vi​(Ai​)≥3n−12n​μi​∀i∈[n].

Let A\mathcal AA be the return of ALGEG. Consider the set of goods that have value ≥12vi(A1)\ge{1\over2}v_i(A_1)≥21​vi​(A1​), specifically define τ=arg⁡min⁡{j∣v1(gj≤12v1(A1)}\tau=\arg\min\{j|v_1(g_j\le{1\over2}v_1(A_1)\}τ=argmin{j∣v1​(gj​≤21​v1​(A1​)}. Let HHH denote the set of high valued goods H={g1,g2,⋯ ,gτ−1}H=\{g_1,g_2,\cdots,g_{\tau-1}\}H={g1​,g2​,⋯,gτ−1​}. In addition, write P=(P1,P2,⋯ ,Pn)\mathcal P=(P_1,P_2,\cdots,P_n)P=(P1​,P2​,⋯,Pn​) to denote the partial allocation that ALGEG computes for HHH.

Let ttt denote the smallest iteration count at which ALGEG assigns a good to a bundle of size 2. Hence, every bundle in the partial allocation of the first t−1t-1t−1 goods is of size at most 2.

ALGEG updates the partial allocation by adding goods to existing bundles. This implies that the cardinalities of bundles is always increasing. Thus for each final AjA_jAj​, there ∃\exist∃ PjP_jPj​ in the partial allocation P\mathcal PP s.t. Pj⊆AjP_j\subseteq A_jPj​⊆Aj​. v1(A1)≥v1(P1)v_1(A_1)\ge v_1(P_1)v1​(A1​)≥v1​(P1​).

Let Q\mathcal QQ be the partial allocation considered by ALGEG at the beginning of the ttt-th iteration. The definition of ttt ensures that ∣Qi∣≤2∀i∈[n]|\mathcal Q_i|\le2\forall i\in[n]∣Qi​∣≤2∀i∈[n]. In the following, we will show that τ≤t\tau\le tτ≤t ,then we get bound ∣Pi∣<2∀i∈[n]|P_i|\lt2\forall i\in[n]∣Pi​∣<2∀i∈[n]. This leas to the inequality τ≤2n\tau\le2nτ≤2n.

…(已经有两个物品了，在添加这个物品时，由于根据算法越到后面添加的越小，所以 v1(A1)≥2v1(gt)v_1(A_1)\ge2v_1(g_t)v1​(A1​)≥2v1​(gt​)。根据定义 gτg_\taugτ​ 是最小标号的满足不等式的，所以 τ≤t\tau\le tτ≤t)

✔️Claim 1. In the partial allocation returned by ALGEG, A\mathcal AA, the following inequality holds for all bundles AiA_iAi​ that satisfy Ai∩{gτ,⋯ ,gm}≠∅A_i\cap\{g_\tau,\cdots,g_m\}\neq\emptyAi​∩{gτ​,⋯,gm​}=∅

v1(A1)≥23v1(Ai)v_1(A_1)\ge{2\over3}v_1(A_i)v1​(A1​)≥32​v1​(Ai​)

Proof by property of EFX: v1(A1)≥v1(Ai)−v1(ga)v_1(A_1)\ge v_1(A_i)-v_1(g_a)v1​(A1​)≥v1​(Ai​)−v1​(ga​). v1(A1)≥2v1(gτ)≥2v1(ga)v_1(A_1)\ge2v_1(g_\tau)\ge2v_1(g_a)v1​(A1​)≥2v1​(gτ​)≥2v1​(ga​).

✔️Claim 2. The partial allocation P\mathcal PP consists of the following bundles:

{g1},{g2},⋯ ,{gn−h},{gn−h+1,gn+h},{gn−h+2,gn+h−1},⋯ ,{gn−1,gn+2},{gn,gn+1}\{g_1\},\{g_2\},\cdots,\{g_{n-h}\},\{g_{n-h+1},g_{n+h}\},\{g_{n-h+2},g_{n+h-1}\},\cdots,\{g_{n-1},g_{n+2}\},\{g_n,g_{n+1}\}{g1​},{g2​},⋯,{gn−h​},{gn−h+1​,gn+h​},{gn−h+2​,gn+h−1​},⋯,{gn−1​,gn+2​},{gn​,gn+1​}

Proof by analyzing behavior of the algorithm.

✔️Claim 3. Every partial allocation of HHH majorizes P\mathcal PP.

Proof by using proposition 1.

…

P\mathcal PP minimize the sum of the largest ttt bundles.

Let ℓ\ellℓ be # of bundles in {A2,A3,⋯ ,An}\{A_2,A_3,\cdots,A_n\}{A2​,A3​,⋯,An​}, that do not contain any good with index greater than τ−1\tau-1τ−1. For every such bundle AiA_iAi​, there exists a unique bundle PjP_jPj​ in P\mathcal PP s.t. Ai=PjA_i=P_jAi​=Pj​. By reindexing, that Pn−ℓ+1,Pn−ℓ+2,⋯ ,PnP_{n-\ell+1},P_{n-\ell+2},\cdots,P_nPn−ℓ+1​,Pn−ℓ+2​,⋯,Pn​ are these ℓ\ellℓ bundles in A\mathcal AA that do not satisfy the condition in claim 1.

Let M\mathcal MM denote a partition of [m][m][m] that achieves the maximin share for player 111. Consider the partial allocation {Mi∩H}i=1n\{M_i\cap H\}_{i=1}^n{Mi​∩H}i=1n​ and index the set s.t. valuation is in ascending order. Claim 3 implies {Mi∩H}i=1n\{M_i\cap H\}_{i=1}^n{Mi​∩H}i=1n​ majorizes P\mathcal PP. Hence, ∑i=n−ℓ+1nv1(Mi∩H)≥∑i=n−ℓ+1nv1(Pi)\sum_{i=n-\ell+1}^nv_1(M_i\cap H)\ge\sum_{i=n-\ell+1}^nv_1(P_i)∑i=n−ℓ+1n​v1​(Mi​∩H)≥∑i=n−ℓ+1n​v1​(Pi​). This inequality and the fact the valuations are monotone lead to the following useful bound:

∑i=n−ℓ+1nv1(Mi)≥∑i=n−ℓ+1nv1(Pi)\sum_{i=n-\ell+1}^nv_1(M_i)\ge\sum_{i=n-\ell+1}^nv_1(P_i)i=n−ℓ+1∑n​v1​(Mi​)≥i=n−ℓ+1∑n​v1​(Pi​)

Recall that Pn−ℓ+1,Pn−ℓ+2,⋯ ,PnP_{n-\ell+1},P_{n-\ell+2},\cdots,P_{n}Pn−ℓ+1​,Pn−ℓ+2​,⋯,Pn​ are bundles in A\mathcal AA, and the remaining n−ℓn-\elln−ℓ bundles of A\mathcal AA satisfy the inequality v1(A1)≥23v1(Ai)v_1(A_1)\ge{2\over3}v_1(A_i)v1​(A1​)≥32​v1​(Ai​). Since v1v_1v1​ is additive, we have ∑i=1nv1(Mi)=∑i=1nv1(Ai)\sum_{i=1}^nv_1(M_i)=\sum_{i=1}^nv_1(A_i)∑i=1n​v1​(Mi​)=∑i=1n​v1​(Ai​). Therefore, inequality above provides the following bound:

∑i=1n−ℓvi(Mi)≤∑i=1n−ℓv1(Ai)≤v1(A1)+(n−ℓ−1)32v1(A1)\sum_{i=1}^{n-\ell}v_i(M_i)\le\sum_{i=1}^{n-\ell}v_1(A_i)\\\le v_1(A_1)+(n-\ell-1){3\over2}v_1(A_1)i=1∑n−ℓ​vi​(Mi​)≤i=1∑n−ℓ​v1​(Ai​)≤v1​(A1​)+(n−ℓ−1)23​v1​(A1​)

Overall, this inequality implies that v1(A1)v_1(A_1)v1​(A1​) is at least 2(n−ℓ)3n−12(n-\ell)\over3n-13n−12(n−ℓ)​ times the average of the n−ℓn-\elln−ℓ sets Mℓ+1,⋯ ,MnM_{\ell+1},\cdots,M_nMℓ+1​,⋯,Mn​. Hence, v1(A1)]≥2n3n−1min⁡j∈[n]vi(Mj)=2n3n−1μ1v_1(A_1)]\ge{2n\over3n-1}\min_{j\in[n]}v_i(M_j)={2n\over3n-1}\mu_1v1​(A1​)]≥3n−12n​minj∈[n]​vi​(Mj​)=3n−12n​μ1​. This completes the proof.

Submodular Valuations

0.210.210.21-MMS is guaranteed to exist and can be found in polynomial time for submodular valuations.

Finding an Approximate Maximin Fair Allocation

We execute the subroutine RoundRobin with threshold τi\tau_iτi​ instead of the actual maximin share μi\mu_iμi​.

RoundRobin takes as input threshold, τi\tau_iτi​s, allocates high-valued goods as singleton bundles. And then partition the remaining goods in a round-robin fashion.

This paper argues: for each agent iii, if τi≤μi\tau_i\le\mu_iτi​≤μi​, the bundle PiP_iPi​ allocated to iii by RoundRobin satisfies vi(Pi)≥13(1−1e)τiv_i(P_i)\ge\frac{1}{3}(1-\frac{1}{e})\tau_ivi​(Pi​)≥31​(1−e1​)τi​.

This guarantee holds independently for each agent iii.

Algorithm ALGSUB starts by setting thresholds τi\tau_iτi​s to be more than the maximin shares. Then, it decreases the threshold for agent iii, if the partition returned by RoundRobin does not satisfy vi(Pi)≥13(1−1e)τiv_i(P_i)\ge\frac{1}{3}(1-\frac{1}{e})\tau_ivi​(Pi​)≥31​(1−e1​)τi​ i.e. τi>μi\tau_i\gt\mu_iτi​>μi​, hence decreasing the threshold is justified.

Pseudo code for RoundRobin: input include {τi}\{\tau_i\}{τi​}

Pseudo code for ALGSUB: process of decreasing τi\tau_iτi​

❓How to initialize τi\tau_iτi​???

🎯🤔Theorem 3. Given a MMS allocation with non-negative, monotone, submodular valuations, the ALGSUB finds, in polynomial time, an allocation satisfies vi(Pi)≥0.21μiv_i(P_i)\ge0.21\mu_ivi​(Pi​)≥0.21μi​ for all i∈[n]i\in[n]i∈[n]. Here μi\mu_iμi​ is the maximin share of agent iii.

Theorem 3 is about the main result for submodular valuations.

Proof by lemma 1.

🤔Lemma 1.

For a given a maximin fair division instance with mmm indivisible goods and nnn agents with non-negative, monotone and submodular valuations, let P\mathcal PP be the allocation returned by RoundRobin with threshold τi≥0\tau_i\ge0τi​≥0. Then, for each agent iii whose input threshold satisfies τi≤μi\tau_i\le\mu_iτi​≤μi​, it holds that

vi(Pi)≥13(1−1e)τi≥0.21τiv_i(P_i)\ge\frac{1}{3}(1-\frac{1}{e})\tau_i\ge0.21\tau_ivi​(Pi​)≥31​(1−e1​)τi​≥0.21τi​

Fix an agent iii and under assumption that τi≤μi\tau_i\le\mu_iτi​≤μi​.

Proof by analyzing behavior of RoundRobin.

Very sophisticated😮

Multilinear Extensions

Definition of multilinear extension: For a function f:2[m]↦Rf:2^{[m]}\mapsto\mathbb Rf:2[m]↦R, the multilinear extension F:[0,1][m]↦RF:[0,1]^{[m]}\mapsto\mathbb RF:[0,1][m]↦R is defined as follows:

F(x)=ER∼x[f(R)]=∑R⊆[m]f(R)(∏g∈Rxg∏g∈[m]╲R(1−xg))F(x)=\mathbb E_{R\sim x}[f(R)]=\sum_{R\subseteq[m]}f(R)\left(\prod_{g\in R}x_g\prod_{g\in[m]\diagdown R}(1-x_g)\right)F(x)=ER∼x​[f(R)]=R⊆[m]∑​f(R)⎝⎛​g∈R∏​xg​g∈[m]╲R∏​(1−xg​)⎠⎞​

sampling from x∈[0,1]mx\in[0,1]^mx∈[0,1]m corresponds to selecting a random subset R⊆[m]R\subseteq[m]R⊆[m] in which each g∈[m]g\in[m]g∈[m] appears independently with probability xgx_gxg​.

Fractional allocation: nnn-tuple χ=(x1,x2,⋯ ,xn)\chi=(x^1,x^2,\cdots,x^n)χ=(x1,x2,⋯,xn) with xi∈[0,1]mx_i\in[0,1]^mxi​∈[0,1]m iff ∑i=1nxgi≤1\sum_{i=1}^nx_g^i\le1∑i=1n​xgi​≤1 for all g∈[m]g\in[m]g∈[m].

A binary fractional allocation corresponds to a partial allocation.

🤔Lemma 2. (Proportionality) Let vi:2[m]↦R+v_i:2^{[m]}\mapsto\mathbb R_+vi​:2[m]↦R+​ denote non-negative, monotone, submodular valuations of agents i∈[n]i\in[n]i∈[n] over mmm indivisible goods. Then the fractional allocation ω=(u1,u2,⋯ ,un)\omega=(u^1,u^2,\cdots,u^n)ω=(u1,u2,⋯,un) in which ui=(1n,1n,⋯ ,1n)∈[0,1]mu^i=(\frac{1}{n},\frac{1}{n},\cdots,\frac{1}{n})\in[0,1]^mui=(n1​,n1​,⋯,n1​)∈[0,1]m for all i∈[n]i\in[n]i∈[n], satisfies Vi(ui)≥(1−1e)μiV_i(u^i)\ge(1-\frac{1}{e})\mu_iVi​(ui)≥(1−e1​)μi​ for all i∈[n]i\in[n]i∈[n]. Here Vi:[0,1]m↦R+V_i:[0,1]^m\mapsto\mathbb R_+Vi​:[0,1]m↦R+​ is the multilinear extension of viv_ivi​, and μi\mu_iμi​ is the maximin share of agent iii.

hard proof, omitted

Conclusion

Algorithm proposed in this paper: approximately fair and sequenceable.

Sequenceable allocation: allocations that can be obtained by ordering the agents and then letting them select their most valued unallocated good one after the other.
entry.summary:
Objective: Explore the concept of the Price of Fairness and Maximin Share (MMS) property.

Activities: Read and present paper

entry.title: 丹麦语 DU 3.2 4 Humør og følelser
entry.content:
Ved du hvem der … 你知道谁……

Modul 2 考试的选题：

Mit studie, Min sprogskole, Min praktik, Min bolig, Min fritidsaktivitet, Mit arbejde

God fornøjelse. 玩的开心。

Hvad er der i vejen med dig? 你咋了？

Hvordan har du det?

miste -r -de -t 丢失，失去

tegnebog -en …bøger …bøgerne 钱包

oplevelse -b -r -rne 经历

dumpe -r -de -t 挂科；倾倒

fejl -en - -ene 失误；错误

Humør/følelser

DanskKinesisk
Jeg er i godt humør我心情好
Jeg er i dårligt humør我心情不好
Jeg er glad我高兴
Jeg er tilfreds我满意
Jeg er lykkelig我很高兴
Jeg er stolt我自豪
Jeg er lettet我放心了
Jeg er ked af det我感到抱歉/伤心
Jeg er ulykkelig我很不高兴
Jeg er sur我很生气
Jeg er vred我生气
Jeg er irriteret我很恼火
Jeg er utilfreds我不满意
Jeg er skuffet我失望
Jeg er bekymret我担心
Jeg er nervøs我紧张
Jeg er bange我害怕
Jeg er spændt我兴奋
Jeg er overrasket我惊讶
Jeg er chokeret我震惊
Jeg er stresset我压力大

Jeg har det

  • godt/fint/o.k.
  • ikke så godt/fint/o.k.

Jeg er

  • i godt humør
  • i dårlig humør

Hun ser sur/glad/vred/skuffet/trist ud. 她看起来很生气/高兴/生气/失望/伤心。

Hun smiler/griner/græder. 她微笑/大笑/哭泣。

At spørge ind til noget - reaktioner

Det lyder godt/spændende! 听起来很棒/令人兴奋！

Super!/Alle tiders!/Sådan!

Det var (da) godt/dejligt!

Hvor godt! 多好啊！

Det kan jeg godt forstå. 我能理解。

Held og lykke! 祝你好运！

God fornøjelse! 享受！

Det lyder ikke så godt.

Det var ikke så godt.

Det var synd! 罪过啊！（表示同情/遗憾）

synd -en -er -erne 罪过

Sikke noget møg! 真是一坨狗屎！（真是一团糟！）

Hvor er det ærgerligt! 多么悲伤！

Spørger ind til noget:

Hvorfor det?/Hvorfor ikke?

Er der sket noget? 发生了什么？

Er der noget i vejen? 有啥不对？/咋了？

Hvad er der sket? 发生了什么？

Hvordan/Hvornår skete det? 如何/啥时候发生的？

Grammatik: Om konjunktioner i hovedsætninger

主句中的连接词，语序为：

S - V, K - S - V

og

tilføjelse 表示添加说明 和

Eks.: Klokken er mange, og han er træt.

men

kontrast/modsætning 表对比/转折 但是，然而

Eks.: Hun var vred, men hun sagde ikke noget.

eller

alternativ 表选择 或者

Eks.: Han er vred, eller han er ked af det.

for

forklaring 表原因 因为

Eks.: Hun er lykkelig, for hun har bestået sin eksamen.

så

konsekvens (= derfor) 表结果 所以

Eks.: Hun har bestået sin eksamen, så hun er lykkelig.
entry.summary:
Ved du hvem der … 你知道谁……

Modul 2 考试的选题：

Mit studie, Min sprogskole, Min praktik, Min bolig, Min fritidsaktivitet, Mit arbej

entry.title: 数据挖掘 5 Outlier Detection
entry.content:
Outlier detection as the task of finding anomalous points in data.

Brief Introduction

Outlier: definition depends on the application. “An object that deviates so much from the rest of the data as to arouse suspicion that it was generated by a different mechanism.”

Noise VS outliers: Noise is a measuring error. Outlier is a point that belongs to the same distribution.

Different types of outliers:

  • Global outliers: Point that significantly deviate from the data set.
  • Contextual outliers: Points deviate from a subset of points. Context is defined as fixed values in some dimensions.
  • Collective outliers: A set of points might represent an outlier w.r.t. the rest of the points. In this case, a single point might not be an outlier, though such is the whole set.

Methods for outlier detection: supervised and unsupervised.

  • Supervised outlier detection requires labels.
  • Unsupervised outlier detected. ✅ We are interested in this one.

This lecture:

  • Low-dimensional
    • model-based
    • depth-based
    • distance-based
  • high-dimensional
    • angle-based
    • local outliers
    • clustering-based
    • isolation forests

Low-dimensional Outlier Detection

Model-based Methods

It assumes that the data is a sample from a known distribution P(X)P(X)P(X). After fitting the parameters θ\thetaθ of the distribution, return the points having low probability P(x)P(\mathbb x)P(x), i.e., points that are unlikely to be generated by the distribution P(X)P(X)P(X).

The simplest model-based method: assuming data D\mathcal DD belongs to a normal distribution

D∼f(x∣μ,Σ)=1(2π)d∣Σ∣exp⁡(−12(x−μ)TΣ−1(x−μ))\mathcal D\sim f(\mathbb x|\mu,\Sigma)={1\over\sqrt{(2\pi)^d|\Sigma|}}\exp(-{1\over2}(x-\mu)^T\Sigma^{-1}(x-\mu))D∼f(x∣μ,Σ)=(2π)d∣Σ∣​1​exp(−21​(x−μ)TΣ−1(x−μ))

A rule of thumb: 3σ3\sigma3σ

The Grubbs’ Test provides a statistical confidence whether the point is generated by the same normal distribution. But only with uni-variate 单变量 data. The test’s null hypothesis H0H_0H0​ is the absence of outliers in the data. Test works as follows:

  1. Compute the Grubbs’ test statistics G=max⁡x∈D∣x−μ∣σG={\max_{\mathbb x\in\mathcal D}|\mathbb x-\mu|\over\sigma}G=σmaxx∈D​∣x−μ∣​

  2. Reject the null hypothesis H0H_0H0​ if

    G>n−1nG\gt\frac{n-1}{\sqrt n}G>n​n−1​tα/n−22n−1+tα/n−22\sqrt\frac{t^2_{\alpha/n-2}}{n-1+t^2_{\alpha/n-2}}n−1+tα/n−22​tα/n−22​​​

    where ttt is the ttt-student distribution.

Other model-based approaches generalize to arbitrary distributions, such as Gaussian mixtures. We fit the model parameters using methods such as Expectation Maximization algorithm…

Pros and Cons

👍

  • Strong statistical foundation
  • Output labels for outliers and non-outliers but can also output a score of outlierdness
  • Efficient to compute and easy to interpret

👎

  • Often work only in the 1-dimensional case
  • Require fixing a model for the data distribution
  • The Gaussian distribution is affected by the dimensionality

Depth-based Approaches

It search for outliers that stands at the border of the data. One such approach is to run the convex hull algorithm to enclose the points inside a shape. The implicit assumption is that outliers are always located at the border of the data space, while the normal points are inside a convex shape.

The algorithm alternates the convex hull algorithm to the removal of the points at the border. The points are marked with the number of iteration in which they have been removed. The number represents the depth of the point.

Finally, the algorithm marks as outliers all the points at the border. The points are marked with number of iteration in which they are removed. The number represents the depth of the point.

Finally the algorithm marks as outliers all the points having a depth ≥t\ge t≥t.

Although simple, depth-based approaches have severe limitations:

  1. The data is assumed to lie on a convex shape. Not the case for multi-modal distributions in which the data contains many clusters.
  2. Convex hull computation is only efficient on low-dimensional data.

For these reasons, depth-based can only be used in specific settings.

Pros and Cons

👍

  • Uses a global reference set for outlier detection
  • Originally outputs a label, but can be extended for scoring easily, take depth as a scoring value for example.

👎

  • The data must be uni-modal.
  • Convex hull computation is usually only efficient in 2D and 3D spaces.

Distance-based Methods

A direct formalization of the outlier notion by Hawkins.

A point p\mathbb pp is an outlier if most points are further than ϵ\epsilonϵ from p\mathbb pp.

Definition: Given a radius ϵ\epsilonϵ and a percentage π\piπ, a point p\mathbb pp is an outlier if at most π\piπ percent of the points x∈D\mathbb x\in\mathcal Dx∈D are at distance less than ϵ\epsilonϵ from p\mathbb pp.

The set of outliers OD\mathcal O_\mathcal DOD​:

OD={p s.t. ∣{x∈D∣dist(p,x)<ϵ}∣∣D∣≤π}\mathcal O_\mathcal D=\{\mathbb p\text{ s.t. }{|\{\mathbb x\in\mathcal D|dist(\mathbb p,\mathbb x)\lt\epsilon\}|\over|\mathcal D|}\le\pi\}OD​={p s.t. ∣D∣∣{x∈D∣dist(p,x)<ϵ}∣​≤π}

Convient notion of outlier score, easy to implement.

However, ϵ,π\epsilon,\piϵ,π are globally defined, distance-based outliers can not detect outliers with different densities.

Pros and Cons

👍

  • Easy to implement
  • Highly interpret-able

👎

  • Effectiveness depends on the choice of distance measure distdistdist
  • Cannot detect collective outliers
  • Sensitive to the choice of ϵ,π\epsilon,\piϵ,π
  • Sensitive to data density

High-dimensional Outlier Detection

Suffers from the curse of dimensionality. In this case outliers hides within inliers and make analyses harder.

Angel-based Outlier Detection

abbr. ABOD

Curse of dimensionality doesn’t affect angles as much as distances. Because the relative positions of the points do not change in higher dimension.

Idea: The angle formed with any pair of other points is typically small in variance.

这个观点很有趣，一个异常值相对于其他点有偏离，所以这个异常值和其他点连线的方向都应该差别不太大。（异常值离聚类越远，连线的夹角越接近。）

ABOD works as follows:

  • Consider the angles formed by a point p\mathbb pp with any point x,y∈D\mathbb x,\mathbb y\in\mathcal Dx,y∈D
  • Plot the angles in a chart
  • The variance of the angles represents an indication on whether a point is an outlier or an inlier.

ABOD measures the variance of angles, weighted by the corresponding distances by

ABOD(p)=VARx,y∈D(⟨x−p,y−p⟩∣∣x−p∣∣2⋅∣∣y−p∣∣2).ABOD(\mathbb p)=VAR_{\mathbb x,\mathbb y\in\mathcal D}\left({\langle\mathbb x-\mathbb p,\mathbb y-\mathbb p\rangle}\over||\mathbb x-\mathbb p||^2\cdot||\mathbb y-\mathbb p||^2\right).ABOD(p)=VARx,y∈D​(∣∣x−p∣∣2⋅∣∣y−p∣∣2⟨x−p,y−p⟩​).

A point with a small ABOD denotes an outlier/ The naive computation of ABOD takes O(n3)\mathcal O(n^3)O(n3) due to the number of pairs for each point.

One possible solution is to consider only a subset of pairs, to get a good approximation to exact ABOD.

Pros and Cons

👍

  • Global approach to outlier detection
  • Performs well on high-dimensional data

👎

  • The naive algorithm runs in O(n3)\mathcal O(n^3)O(n3)
  • Cannot detect collective outliers

Local Methods

A point is a outlier if local density is larger than that of its own neighbors.

Local outliers are defined in terms of nearest neighbors and require only to specify the parameter to define how many neighbor points to consider.

One of local outlier methods is the Local Outlier Factor.

The KNN distance is the distance distk(p)dist_k(\mathbb p)distk​(p) between a point p\mathbb pp and its k-nearest neighbor.

Reachability distance sets a lower bound between the KNN distance and the distance of a point x\mathbb xx from a point p\mathbb pp

rdistk(p,x)=max⁡{distk(x),dist(p,x)}rdist_k(\mathbb p,\mathbb x)=\max\{dist_k(\mathbb x),dist(\mathbb p,\mathbb x)\}rdistk​(p,x)=max{distk​(x),dist(p,x)}

The local reachability distance (lrd) of a point p\mathbb pp is the average inverse reachability distance of a point p\mathbb pp from its KNN. The higher the lrd(p)lrd(\mathbb p)lrd(p), the closer p\mathbb pp is to its k-nearest points.

lrdk(p)=1∣Nk(p)∣1∑x∈Nk(p)rdistk(p,x)lrd_k(\mathbb p)={1\over|N_k(\mathbb p)|}{1\over\sum_{x\in N_k(\mathbb p)}rdist_k(\mathbb p,\mathbb x)}lrdk​(p)=∣Nk​(p)∣1​∑x∈Nk​(p)​rdistk​(p,x)1​

Finally the Local Outlier Factor (LOF) is the average ratio of the local reachability distances of the neighbors of p\mathbb pp and that of p\mathbb pp. The local outlier factor measures the relative density of the neighbors of a point and point it self.

LOFk(p)=1∣Nk(p)∣∑x∈Nk(p)lrdk(x)lrdk(p)LOF_k(\mathbb p)={1\over|N_k(\mathbb p)|}\sum_{\mathbb x\in N_k(\mathbb p)}{lrd_k(\mathbb x)\over lrd_k(\mathbb p)}LOFk​(p)=∣Nk​(p)∣1​x∈Nk​(p)∑​lrdk​(p)lrdk​(x)​

If the density of points around p\mathbb pp is less than the density around its neighbors, the LOF will be large.

LOF solves curse of dimensionality. However, LOF struggles in regions with low-density.

Pros and Cons

👍

  • Provides a scores of outlierdness
  • Easy interpret-ability
  • Not affected by the curse of dimensionality

👎

  • Inefficient due to the computation of the neighbors
  • Requires the correct setting of the parameter kkk
  • Hard to detect outliers in low-density regions

Clustering-based Methods

e.g. in DBSCAN, every object not contained in a cluster must be an outlier.

FindCBLOF. In order to find outliers using clustering techniques we can use a general method called FindCBLOF.

  • Compute clusters using a clustering algorithm
  • Sort the clusters in decreasing order by number of points
  • Assign to each point a cluster-based local outlier factor (CBLOF)
    • If point p\mathbb pp belongs to a large cluster CiC_iCi​, then CBLOF(p)=∣Ci∣⋅SCBLOF(\mathbb p)=|C_i|\cdot SCBLOF(p)=∣Ci​∣⋅S, where SSS is similarity between p\mathbb pp and the cluster.
    • If p\mathbb pp belongs to a small cluster, then CBLOF(p)=∣Ci∣⋅SCBLOF(\mathbb p)=|C_i|\cdot SCBLOF(p)=∣Ci​∣⋅S, where SSS is the similarity between p\mathbb pp and the closest large cluster.

Pros and Cons

👍

  • Detect outliers without requiring labeled data
  • Works on several types of data
  • Clusters can be regarded as summaries of data

👎

  • The effectiveness depends on the chosen clustering method
  • High computational cost to compute the clusters

Isolation Forest

abbr. IF is a method to detect outliers based on the notion of separability.

p\mathbb pp is separable if it is easy to find a random hyper-plane that separates the point from the rest. Idea is similar to a decision tree.

The probability of a point p\mathbb pp to be separated from the others in a random split of the data is higher if the point is an outlier. This means that such point with high probability, a leaf close to the root of a randomly-built decision tree.

However, the point p\mathbb pp can also be separated by chance. As such, the algorithm builds a number of trees (forest) and calculates the expected height E(h(p))\mathbb E(h(\mathbb p))E(h(p)) of the root-leaf path and uses such expectation to compute an outlier score

s(p)=2−E(h(p))/c(n)s(\mathbb p)=2^{-\mathbb E(h(\mathbb p))/c(n)}s(p)=2−E(h(p))/c(n)

where c(n)c(n)c(n) is the expected path length of a balanced binary search tree with nnn data points used for normalization. An outlier has a score close to 1, i.e. the expected length of the path from the root to the leaf h(p)≈0h(\mathbb p)\approx0h(p)≈0.

Pros and Cons

👍

  • Easy to construct avoiding difficult decisions on if data points are anomalies or not.
  • Can achieve sublinear time complexity and a small memory footprint by exploiting sub-sampling. By eliminating major computational cost of distance calculation in all the distance and density based AD methods
  • Can provide anomaly explanations

👎

  • Hyperparameter tuning required such as number of trees, sample size and heights of trees.
  • Requires a high percentage of relevant features to identity anomalies.
entry.summary: Outlier detection as the task of finding anomalous points in data.

entry.title: 随机算法 5 Streaming Algorithms for Frequency Estimation
entry.content:
Lecture notes adopted from UCB CS270

Streaming Algorithms: Frequent Items

Streaming setting: Data stream x1,x2,⋯ ,xnx_1,x_2,\cdots,x_nx1​,x2​,⋯,xn​ with xi∈[m]x_i\in[m]xi​∈[m]. The available memory is O(log⁡cn)O(\log^cn)O(logcn). Sub-linear space.

Algorithm: Approximates frequencies for the top kkk items.

Deterministic Algorithm

To estimate item frequencies fjf_jfj​ within an additive error of n/kn/kn/k using with O(klog⁡n)O(k\log n)O(klogn) memory. （log⁡n\log nlogn 这里指的是内存的比特数量。）

  • Maintain set SSS of kkk counters, initialize to 000. For each element xix_ixi​ in stream
    • If xi∈Sx_i\in Sxi​∈S, increment the counter of xix_ixi​.
    • If xi∉Sx_i\not\in Sxi​∈S, add xix_ixi​ to SSS is space is available, else decrement all counters in SSS.

An item in SSS whose count falls to 000 can be removed, the space requirement for storing kkk counters is klog⁡nk\log nklogn and the update time per item is O(k)O(k)O(k). The algorithm estimates the count of an item as the value of its counter or zero if it has no counter.

🤔Claim 1: The frequency estimate njn_jnj​ produced by the algorithm satisfies fj−n/k≤nj≤fjf_j-n/k\le n_j\le f_jfj​−n/k≤nj​≤fj​.

Clearly, njn_jnj​ is less than the true frequency fjf_jfj​. Differences between fjf_jfj​ and the value of the estimate are caused by one of the two scenarios:

  1. The item j∉Sj\not\in Sj∈S, each counter in SSS gets decremented, this is the case when xjx_jxj​ occurs in the stream but the counter for jjj is not incremented.
  2. The counter for jjj gets decremented due to an element j′j'j′ that is not contained in SSS.

Both scenarios result in kkk counters getting decremented hence they can occur at most n/kn/kn/k times, showing that nj≥fj−n/kn_j\ge f_j-n/knj​≥fj​−n/k.

在所有计数器减少前，至少要添加 kkk 次。对于所有计数器的和，每次减少操作都会减少 kkk。所有计数器的和最多减少 n/kn/kn/k 次。所以单个计数器也最多减少 n/kn/kn/k 次。

也就是当所有 item 出现的频率都一样（都是 n/kn/kn/k）的时候，取等号。

Count Min Sketch

The turnstile model (旋转门模型) allows both additions and deletions of items in the stream.

The stream consists of pairs (i,ci)(i,c_i)(i,ci​), where the i∈[m]i\in[m]i∈[m] is an item and cic_ici​ is the number of items to be added or deleted. The count of an item can not be negative at any stage, the frequency fjf_jfj​ of item jjj is fj=∑cjf_j=\sum c_jfj​=∑cj​.

The following algorithm estimates frequencies of all items up to an additive error of ϵ∣f∣1\epsilon|f|_1ϵ∣f∣1​ with probability 1−δ1-\delta1−δ, the ℓ1\ell_1ℓ1​ norm ∣f∣1|f|_1∣f∣1​ is the number of items present in the data set. The two parameters kkk and ttt in the algorithm are chosen to be 2ϵ,log⁡(1/δ){2\over\epsilon},\log(1/\delta)ϵ2​,log(1/δ).

Space usage: O(1ϵlog⁡n)O({1\over\epsilon}\log n)O(ϵ1​logn)

The algorithm works as follows:

  1. Maintain ttt arrays A[i]A[i]A[i] each having kkk counters, hash function hi:U→[k]h_i:U\rarr[k]hi​:U→[k] drawn from a 222-wise independent family H\mathcal HH is associated to array A[i]A[i]A[i].

  2. For element (j,cj)(j,c_j)(j,cj​) in the stream, update counters as follows:

    A[i,hi(j)]←A[i,hi(j)]+cj∀i∈[t]A[i,h_i(j)]\gets A[i,h_i(j)]+c_j\forall i\in[t]A[i,hi​(j)]←A[i,hi​(j)]+cj​∀i∈[t]

  3. The frequency estimate for item jjj is min⁡i∈[t]A[i,h(j)]\min_{i\in[t]}A[i,h(j)]mini∈[t]​A[i,h(j)].

The output estimate is always more than the true value of fjf_jfj​ as the count of all the items in the stream is non-negative.

Analysis

To bound the error in the estimate for fjf_jfj​ we need to analyze the excess XXX where A[1,h1(j)]=fj+XA[1,h_1(j)]=f_j+XA[1,h1​(j)]=fj​+X. The excess XXX an be a sum of random variables X=∑iYiX=\sum_iY_iX=∑i​Yi​ where Yi=fiY_i=f_iYi​=fi​ if h1(j)=h1(i)h_1(j)=h_1(i)h1​(j)=h1​(i) and 000 otherwise. As h1∈Hh_1\in\mathcal Hh1​∈H is chosen uniformly at random from a pair-wise independent hash function family, E[Yi]=fi/k\mathbb E[Y_i]=f_i/kE[Yi​]=fi​/k.

E[X]=∣f∣1k=ϵ∣f∣12.\mathbb E[X]={|f|_1\over k}={\epsilon|f|_1\over2}.E[X]=k∣f∣1​​=2ϵ∣f∣1​​.

E[X]=Eh[∑j≠i,h(i)=h(j)fj]=Eh[∑j∣j≠ifj⋅1h(i)=h(j)]=∑j∣j≠iE[1h(i)=h(j)]⋅fj=∑j∣j≠iPr⁡[h(i)=h(j)]⋅fj=∑j∣j≠ifjk≤∑jfjk=∣f∣1k\mathbb E[X]=\mathbb E_h[\sum_{j\neq i,h(i)=h(j)}f_j]=\mathbb E_h[\sum_{j|j\neq i}f_j\cdot\mathbf 1_{h(i)=h(j)}]\\=\sum_{j|j\neq i}\mathbb E[\mathbf 1_{h(i)=h(j)}]\cdot f_j=\sum_{j|j\neq i}\Pr[h(i)=h(j)]\cdot f_j=\sum_{j|j\neq i}{f_j\over k}\le{\sum_jf_j\over k}={|f|_1\over k}E[X]=Eh​[j=i,h(i)=h(j)∑​fj​]=Eh​[j∣j=i∑​fj​⋅1h(i)=h(j)​]=j∣j=i∑​E[1h(i)=h(j)​]⋅fj​=j∣j=i∑​Pr[h(i)=h(j)]⋅fj​=j∣j=i∑​kfj​​≤k∑j​fj​​=k∣f∣1​​

Applying Markov’s inequality, we have

Pr⁡[X>ϵ∣f∣1]≤12.\Pr[X\gt\epsilon|f|_1]\le{1\over2}.Pr[X>ϵ∣f∣1​]≤21​.

The probability that all the excesses at A[i,hi(xi)]A[i,h_i(x_i)]A[i,hi​(xi​)] are greater than ϵ∣f∣1\epsilon|f|_1ϵ∣f∣1​ is at most 12t≤δ{1\over2^t}\le\delta2t1​≤δ as ttt was chosen to be log⁡(1/δ)\log(1/\delta)log(1/δ). The algorithm estimates the frequency of item xjx_jxj​ up to an additive error ϵ∣f∣1\epsilon|f|_1ϵ∣f∣1​ with probability 1−δ1-\delta1−δ.

The memory required for the algorithm is the sum of the space for the array and the hash functions, O(ktlog⁡n+tlog⁡m)=O(1ϵlog⁡(1/δ)log⁡n)O(kt\log n+t\log m)=O({1\over\epsilon}\log(1/\delta)\log n)O(ktlogn+tlogm)=O(ϵ1​log(1/δ)logn). The update time per item in the stream is O(log⁡1δ)O(\log{1\over\delta})O(logδ1​).

Count Sketch

Another sketch algorithm with error in terms of the ℓ2\ell_2ℓ2​ norm ∣f∣2=∑jfj2|f|_2=\sqrt{\sum_jf_j^2}∣f∣2​=∑j​fj2​​.

The relation between the ℓ1\ell_1ℓ1​ and ℓ2\ell_2ℓ2​ norm is 1n∣f∣1≤∣f∣2≤∣f∣1{1\over\sqrt n}|f|_1\le|f|_2\le|f|_1n​1​∣f∣1​≤∣f∣2​≤∣f∣1​, the ℓ2\ell_2ℓ2​ norm is less than the ℓ1\ell_1ℓ1​ norm so the guarantee for this algorithm is better than that for the previous one.

The algorithm works as follows:

  1. Maintain ttt arrays A[i]A[i]A[i] each having kkk counters, hash function: gi:U→{−1,1}g_i:U\rarr\{-1,1\}gi​:U→{−1,1} and hi:U→[k]h_i:U\rarr[k]hi​:U→[k] drawn uniformly at random from a pair-wise independent families are associated to array A[i]A[i]A[i].

  2. For element (j,cj)(j,c_j)(j,cj​) in the stream, update counters as follows

    A[i,hi(j)]←A[i,hi(j)]+gi(j)cj∀i∈[t]A[i,h_i(j)]\gets A[i,h_i(j)]+g_i(j)c_j\forall i\in[t]A[i,hi​(j)]←A[i,hi​(j)]+gi​(j)cj​∀i∈[t]

  3. The frequency estimate for item jjj is the median over the ttt arrays of gi(xj)A[i,h(j)]g_i(x_j)A[i,h(j)]gi​(xj​)A[i,h(j)].

Analysis

The entry A[1,h1(j)]=g1(j)fj+XA[1,h_1(j)]=g_1(j)f_j+XA[1,h1​(j)]=g1​(j)fj​+X, we examine the contribution XXX from the other items by writing X=∑iYiX=\sum_iY_iX=∑i​Yi​ where YYY is ±fi\pm f_i±fi​ if h1(i)=h1(j)h_1(i)=h_1(j)h1​(i)=h1​(j) and 000 otherwise. Note that E[Yj]=0\mathbb E[Y_j]=0E[Yj​]=0, so the expected value of g1(j)A[1,h(j)]g_1(j)A[1,h(j)]g1​(j)A[1,h(j)] is fjf_jfj​.

fi^=g(i)⋅A[h(i)]=g(i)⋅(g(i)⋅fi+∑j≠i,h(j)=h(i)g(j)⋅fj)=fi+∑j≠i,h(j)=h(i)g(i)g(j)fj=fi+XE[X]=E[∑j≠i,h(j)=h(i)g(i)g(j)fj]=E[∑j≠i1h(i)=h(j)g(i)g(j)fj]=∑j≠iE[1h(i)=h(j)g(i)g(j)]fj=∑j≠iE[1h(i)=h(j)]E[g(i)]E[g(j)]fj=0\hat{f_i}=g(i)\cdot A[h(i)]=g(i)\cdot(g(i)\cdot f_i+\sum_{j\neq i,h(j)=h(i)}g(j)\cdot f_j)\\=f_i+\sum_{j\neq i,h(j)=h(i)}g(i)g(j)f_j\\=f_i+X\\\mathbb E[X]=\mathbb E[\sum_{j\neq i,h(j)=h(i)}g(i)g(j)f_j]=\mathbb E[\sum_{j\neq i}\mathbf1_{h(i)=h(j)}g(i)g(j)f_j]\\=\sum_{j\neq i}\mathbb E[\mathbf1_{h(i)=h(j)}g(i)g(j)]f_j=\sum_{j\neq i}\mathbb E[\mathbf 1_{h(i)=h(j)}]\mathbb E[g(i)]\mathbb E[g(j)]f_j=0\\fi​^​=g(i)⋅A[h(i)]=g(i)⋅(g(i)⋅fi​+j=i,h(j)=h(i)∑​g(j)⋅fj​)=fi​+j=i,h(j)=h(i)∑​g(i)g(j)fj​=fi​+XE[X]=E[j=i,h(j)=h(i)∑​g(i)g(j)fj​]=E[j=i∑​1h(i)=h(j)​g(i)g(j)fj​]=j=i∑​E[1h(i)=h(j)​g(i)g(j)]fj​=j=i∑​E[1h(i)=h(j)​]E[g(i)]E[g(j)]fj​=0

The random variable YiY_iYi​ are pairwise independent as h1h_1h1​ is a pair-wise independent hash function, so the variance of XXX:

Var(X)=∑i∈[m]Var(Yi)=∑i∈[m]fi2k=∣f∣22k.Var(X)=\sum_{i\in[m]}Var(Y_i)=\sum_{i\in[m]}{f^2_i\over k}={|f|_2^2\over k}.Var(X)=i∈[m]∑​Var(Yi​)=i∈[m]∑​kfi2​​=k∣f∣22​​.

By Chebyshev’s inequality,

Pr⁡[∣X−μ∣>Δ]≤Var(X)Δ2.\Pr[|X-\mu|\gt\Delta]\le{Var(X)\over\Delta^2}.Pr[∣X−μ∣>Δ]≤Δ2Var(X)​.

The mean μ=0\mu=0μ=0 and the variance is ∣f∣22k|f|_2^2\over kk∣f∣22​​, choosing δ=ϵ∣f∣2\delta=\epsilon|f|_2δ=ϵ∣f∣2​ and k=4/ϵ2k=4/\epsilon^2k=4/ϵ2, we have

Pr⁡[∣X−μ∣>ϵ∣f∣2]≤1ϵ2k≤14.\Pr[|X-\mu|\gt\epsilon|f|_2]\le{1\over\epsilon^2k}\le{1\over4}.Pr[∣X−μ∣>ϵ∣f∣2​]≤ϵ2k1​≤41​.

For t=θ(log⁡(1/δ))t=\theta(\log(1/\delta))t=θ(log(1/δ)), the probability that the median value deviates from μ\muμ by more than ϵ∣f∣2\epsilon|f|_2ϵ∣f∣2​ is less than δ\deltaδ by a Chernoff Bound. That is, the probability that there are fewer than t/2t/2t/2 success in a series of ttt tosses of a coin with success probability 343\over443​ is smaller than δ\deltaδ for t=O(log⁡(1δ))t=O(\log({1\over\delta}))t=O(log(δ1​)).

Arguing as in the count min sketch the space required is O(1ϵ2log⁡1δlog⁡n)O({1\over\epsilon^2}\log{1\over\delta}\log n)O(ϵ21​logδ1​logn) and the update time per item is O(log⁡1δ)O(\log{1\over\delta})O(logδ1​).

Remarks

  • The count sketch approximates fjf_jfj​ within ϵ∣f∣2\epsilon|f|_2ϵ∣f∣2​ but requires O~(1ϵ2)\widetilde O({1\over\epsilon^2})O(ϵ21​) space,

  • while the count min sketch approximates fjf_jfj​ within ϵ∣f∣1\epsilon|f|_1ϵ∣f∣1​ and requires O~(1ϵ)\widetilde O({1\over\epsilon})O(ϵ1​).

  • The approximation provided by the sketch algorithm is meaningful only for items that occur with high frequency.
